message.content:
<<<api>>>: PrintWriter.write
<<<code>>>: import java.io.PrintWriter;
import java.util.*;

public class PrimeByVector {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        final int NUMBER_PER_LINE = 10;
        int count = 0;
        Vector<Integer> vector = new Vector<>();
        System.out.println("The primes before 92 are: \n");
        for (int n = 2; n < 92; n++) {
            boolean isPrime = true;
            for (int i = 0; i < vector.size(); i++) {
                int primeNumber = vector.elementAt(i);
                if (primeNumber > Math.sqrt(n)) break;
                if (n % primeNumber == 0) {
                    isPrime = false;
                    break;
                }
            }
            if (isPrime) {
                count++;
                vector.addElement(n);
                if (count % NUMBER_PER_LINE == 0) {
                    System.out.println(n);
                } else
                    System.out.print(n + " ");
            }
        }
        try {
            PrintWriter writer = new PrintWriter("VectorDump", "UTF-8");
            for (Integer num : vector) {
                writer.write(num + " ");
            }
            writer.close();
        } catch (Exception e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }
    }
}
<<<explanation>>>: The PrintWriter class in Java is used to write characters to a file in a convenient way. In this code, after calculating the prime numbers, we create a PrintWriter object that writes to a file named "VectorDump". We then iterate over the vector of prime numbers, converting each number to a string and writing it to the file. After all numbers have been written, we close the PrintWriter. If an exception occurs during this process, it is caught and its stack trace is printed.

Answer:<<<api>>>: Arrays.stream
<<<code>>>: int[] array = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5};
int sum = Arrays.stream(array).sum();
<<<explanation>>>: The sum() method of the IntStream class returns the sum of elements in this stream. This is a special case of a reduction. This is a terminal operation.
